references.paper_title: Deal or no deal? end-to-end learning for negotiation dialogues
references.reason: This paper introduces the "Deal or No Deal" game dataset, which is used as a benchmark in this study for evaluating LLMs' negotiation capabilities in incomplete-information scenarios.

references.paper_title: Large language models as simulated economic agents: What can we learn from homo silicus?
references.reason: This paper offers a valuable perspective on using LLMs as simulated economic agents in game theory contexts, contributing to the theoretical understanding of LLM capabilities in strategic decision-making.

references.paper_title: Cogbench: a large language model walks into a psychology lab
references.reason: This work provides insights into the cognitive capabilities of LLMs, highlighting their ability to navigate game-theoretic scenarios and perform strategic decision-making.
This study introduces the concept of chain-of-thought prompting, which is used extensively in this paper to enhance the rationality of LLMs in various game-theoretic scenarios.
This book is a foundational text in game theory, and its principles are implicitly applied throughout this research for analyzing the rational behavior of agents in strategic settings.
